title: Homemade crispy chilli oil
time: Hands-on time 30 min, plus overnight infusing
description: This is a full-flavoured, in-your-face crispy chilli oil, with plenty of fire, spice and floral numbness from the Sichuan peppercorns. Use it as a base recipe to then tweak, amend and experiment with until you’ve found your perfect combination.
ingredients: 25g chilli flakes, or crushed dried chillies

title: Prawn and lemongrass hot and sour soup
description: Georgina Hayden’s fragrant hot and sour soup is packed with prawns, noodles and zingy fresh herbs. Batch cook and freeze the broth ready for busy nights.
ingredients: 2 lemongrass stalks, trimmed and roughly chopped
150g oyster and/or enoki mushrooms, roughly torn
4 spring onions, trimmed and finely sliced, to serve
½ bunch of coriander and/or mint, leaves picked, to serve

title: Steamed lap cheong with five treasure fried rice
portion: Serves 4, or 6 with other side dishes
description: Lap cheong, Chinese sausages, are the jewel in these steaming bowls of five-treasure fried rice, packed with prawns, egg and vegetables.
ingredients: 2 lap cheong (Chinese wind-dried sausage; available from Asian supermarkets or souschef.co.uk)
Bunch spring onions, finely sliced on an angle
2 tbsp light soy sauce or tamari
1 tbsp crispy chilli oil or toasted sesame oil, plus extra to serve

title: Jeremy Pang’s General Tso’s chicken
description: Learn how to make General Tso’s chicken with expert chef Jeremy Pang. The popular wok-fried chicken dish is the perfect balance of sweet, sour, spicy, savoury and salty. You’re going to love it.
ingredients: 200g cornflour, seasoned with ¼ tsp salt and ¼ tsp pepper
½ thumb-size piece ginger, finely sliced
½ tbsp black rice vinegar (see Easy Swaps and Know How)

title: MiMi Mei Fair’s ‘Hokkien’ noodles
description: These noodles are a celebration dish worth making. Whether you’re cooking up a feast for Chinese New Year or simply a Friday night, Peter Ho of London restaurant MiMi Mei Fair has created a next-level Hokkien noodle dish. The delicate balance of fish sauce, Chinese chicken powder and ground white pepper makes for an umami sensation that’ll have you coming back for seconds.
ingredients: 2 sustainable scallops, sliced in half horizontally (defrosted if needs be)
3 sustainable raw king prawns, sliced in half horizontally (defrosted if needs be)
100g yellow egg noodles, cooked (or use straight-to-wok noodles)
100g rice vermicelli noodles, cooked (or use straight-to-wok noodles)
1 tsp chicken powder (eg chicken stock cube or bouillon or see Tips)

title: Giant prawn toast
description: Giant prawn toast is a great sharing dish for Friday nights. Our mega prawn toast with dipping sauce is a fun riff on a takeaway favourite.
ingredients: 1 small (400g) loaf soft white unsliced bread
12 sustainable raw Scottish langoustines (or use sustainable North Atlantic prawns)
Small bunch coriander, chopped, plus extra leaves to serve
4 tbsp sesame seeds, plus extra to serve

title: Wun’s kung pao chicken
portion: Serves 3-4 as part of a meal
description: Discover how to make the perfect kung pao chicken with this step-by-step recipe from chef Arty Florea of Wun’s Tea Room in London.
ingredients: 65ml black rice vinegar (or use regular rice wine vinegar)
Blender or large pestle and mortar

title: Crispy pork potsticker dumplings
portion: Makes 20 dumplings (serves 2 as a meal or 3-4 as a snack)
description: Some say potstickers, which originated in China and have become a worldwide favourite, came about when a chef let his dumplings boil dry, stick to the pan and crisp up. Make these beauties and they won’t stick around for long.
ingredients: 60g chinese leaf /napa cabbage, shredded and chopped
2 spring onions, finely sliced, plus extra to serve
3 garlic cloves, finely chopped or grated
2 tsp ginger, finely chopped or grated
1 tbsp shaoxing rice wine vinegar (or good quality dry sherry)
2 tbsp rice wine vinegar or Chinese black rice vinegar

title: Hunan-style crispy mushroom noodle salad
portion: Serves 2-4 as part of a meal
time: Hands-on time 30 min, oven time 15 min
description: Ching-He Huang’s vegan Chinese mushroom noodle salad combines panko-fried shimeji mushrooms, rice noodles and loads of veg for a tasty, healthy meal.
ingredients: 1 tbsp tamari or reduced-salt light soy sauce
1 large carrot, cut into fine matchsticks
Spring onion curls to serve (see tip)

title: Black bean tofu and baby pak choi
portion: Serves 2 as a main or 4 as a side
description: Ching-He Huang’s healthy vegan recipe with black bean tofu and baby pak choi is a winner for vegan Chinese New Year celebrations.
ingredients: 1 bird’s eye chilli, deseeded and chopped
1 tbsp fermented salted black beans, rinsed and lightly crushed (see Know-how)
1 tbsp yellow bean or miso paste (see Know-how)
1 tbsp shaohsing rice wine or dry sherry (see Know-how)
2 green peppers, deseeded and cut into 1.5cm chunks
200ml vegetable stock (vegan if it needs to be)
1 tbsp tamari or reduced-salt light soy sauce
1 tbsp tamari or reduced-salt light soy sauce
2.5cm piece fresh ginger, sliced into matchsticks
